comments.body: why this change?

Previously the deployment was using 3 replicas and a maxUnavailable of 1. This meant that rollover could be exercised, eg.

rs-1: 3 pods
==update==>
rs-1: 2 pods, rs-2: 2 pods
==deployment blocks because rs-2 is broken==>
==new update==>
rs-1 and rs-2 are rolled over by rs-3

Now that the deployment uses 1 pod, we need maxUnavailable=0 for continuing to exercise rollover
the below can be wrapped in a func ensureReplicas(n) and reused above, but I guess it is fine
agreed, will update

comments.body: Switch maxUnavailable to 0 and this to 1?

Can't do this, since rollover test requires at least 3 replicas: it creates an RS first, then create a deployment that creates another RS, and then before the rolling update finishes, update deployment to create the third RS to rollover the first two versions

- RS-1 has one healthy replica
- D with maxUnavailable=0 creates RS-2 with one unhealthy replica. It shouldn't scale down RS-1 otherwise it violates availability.
- D is updated. RS-3 is scaled up to one. POD-3 becomes healthy, RS-2 and RS-1 are scaled down

Seems doable.

nit: a new rollout and scale
Because scaling will happen randomnly even at this point, this will not be correct for all the cases. I am already logging when a scale is triggered.
and scale
Same comment as https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/35691#discussion_r85926418
What's the reason behind this number?
It's for creating a random wait between actions. The more the test proceeds, the more the waits will be longer so we can test various action rates.
This was fairly effective at exposing races and bad logic in the deployment controller in openshift.

Found the first race in the scaling code: http://pastebin.com/fwwEfJnp
Fast updates can block rollouts because the replica annotations are not updated correctly in the scale code.
We should check that the strategy isn't violated (something like `framework.WaitForDeploymentStatus`) in this test.

comments.body: Would be good to add a comment here describing briefly here what this function tests.
Done

I will suggest keeping the desired replicas very high like 10 or 20 rather than 4 to ensure that this never fails.
In newDeployment, you can change desired replicas to something small like 4.

If we do this, `waitForDeploymentStatus` will always fail. 
1. The first rc creates 10 replicas. 
2. The deployment with 10 replicas is created. Total replicas = 9 (first rc scaled down to 8 and deployment rc scaled up to 1). 
3. The deployment is updated and requires 4 replicas now. `waitForDeploymentStatus` immediately errors "total pods created: 9, more than the max allowed: 5".
Plus this caused longer wait (more than 5 minutes). I'll keep the old settings for replicas.
